Problem:
Consider a linear system characterized by the integral transformation \\( y(t) = \\int_0^t e^{A(s-t)} x(s) ds \\), with A being a constant square matrix. The input function \\( x(t) \\) is transformed using the function \\( g(t, x) = e^{Bt} x \\), where B is also a constant matrix.

If \\( g(t, x) \\) is applied to the input function \\( x_0(t) \\) at t = 0, and the system is then allowed to evolve under the given integral transformation without further intervention, will \\( y(T) \\) at T be the same as if \\( x_0(t) \\) was directly used in the transformation to T?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(t, x) \\) modifies the input function, thus changing the initial conditions of the transformation. The matrix exponential \\( e^{Bt} \\) potentially alters the nature of \\( x(t) \\) contributing to different results in the transformed output \\( y(T) \\) due to variation in integration with respect to the modified input.

causal_map_integration: The application of the transformation g(t, x_0) to the initial input x_0(t) at t=0 yields x(t), which then directly influences y(t) through the integral transformation defined by A. Therefore, y(T) resulting from x(t) is the same as y(T) resulting from x_0(t) directly, assuming no further intervention.
